text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Shareholders' lobby group VEB formulates rules for companies' share options schemes. (p1)
- Debate in parliament on working below minimum wages grinds to a halt. (p1)
- Bank insurer ING unit Nationale Nederlanden books 12.5 pct higher 1996 net profit at 802 million guilders. (p1)
- China's ambassador Mrs Zhu Manli mildly reprimands the Netherlands for interfering in China over human rights. (p1)
- Charter company Martinair reckons with improved 1997 results after a bad 1996. (p3)
- Management consultant Twijnstra Gudde books 8.8 pct higher operating results on 19 pct turnover growth last year. (p3)
- Technical wholesaler Otra forecasts profits increase for 1997 after profits drop in 1996. (p4)
- Insurer Reaal reports 1996 profit up to Dfl 77.7 million from Dfl 50.4 million, boosted by takeover of insurer Hooge Huys. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- Former director of now defunct broker Nusse Brink files complaint against accountancy group KPMG. (p2)
- Grand Hotel Krasnapolsky buys The Lord Charles Hotel in Cape Town South Africa. (p2)
- Trade in computers is getting increasingly more important for the Dutch economy. (p15)
- European court of justice gives Dutch some scope to uphold fixed book prices. (p15)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Central planning bureau CPB wants to put up pension age to avoid problems with financing the pension scheme in future. (p3)
- Dutch federation of tax advisers presents fiscal plan for the next century. (p23)
- Brewer Heineken sees strong growth in Japan. (p25)
- Finnish-Dutch motor builder Stork-Waertsilae on the eve of a big expansion. (p27)
TROUW
- Dutch customs at Schiphol Airport intercepts box with seven mummified heads and the corpse of a baby. (p1)
- European commission wants lower subsidies for shipbuilding industry. (p6)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Royal Dutch/Shell managers were holding Dfl 1.3 bn worth of share options on January 1. (p1)
- Dutch road transport association TLN wants four new rail shuttles this year. (p13)
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040
